content.description: This is the right of the two bolted lines. Easy face climbing leads to a thoughtful crux just above the second bolt. It's smooth sailing after that to the anchor.
This is the left of the two bolted lines and is just right of a prow. Climb up the face using the prow to a ledge. The climbing then eases to a bolted anchor.

This is a fun 5.9 located towards the left end of Scorpio Crag, about a 1/4 mile northwest of the

Lord of La Junta

roof. The route is located about 100 yards northwest of the Class 3 access as described on the main page for Scorpio Crag. The beginning of the route is identifiable by two side-by-side hueco-type formations in white rock.

Climb white, steep, featured rock up and right, and then move back left as the rock turns into more solid sandstone. Fire up the face on positive holds via small cracks and horizontals to the top.
content.protection: TR. You can access the top of the route via a 4th class step just to the left and around the corner from the base of the climb. Bring several hand-sized cams and webbing for making an anchor.
content.location: It is at the far left end of the Scorpio Crag, about 20 yards left of the 4th Class step and 100 yards right of the Class 3 step.

content.description:
Begin up the white-colored rock with sharp crimps. The crux is getting past the second bolt. Thin, techy feet then leads to fun, semi-overhung climbing with hidden horizontal rails and pockets. A hand-sized piece could supplement the minor runout from the last bolt to the anchor; the climbing is only 5.8.

Origami Dog shares anchors with

Helicopter Premonition

.
content.location:
Start 10 feet right of

Helicopter Premonition

and 50 feet right of

Lord of La Junta

(the giant roof with a horizontal crack).

content.description: This is the largest roof at the cliff and isn't to be missed. Climb a fantastic hand crack to the roof. Then undercling right out of the roof where the gear can be a little funky. Pull the crux out of the roof, and then face climb to the top. Despite the upper half appearing chossy, the rock is surprisingly good. Belay off a gear anchor.
content.protection: Hand-sized gear to a blue TCU. The roof eats up small finger-sized gear.

content.description:
This is a fine finger crack 30 feet left of

Crack Left

/

Right

that leads up the cliff to a bolted anchor. This is right of the two sport routes.
content.protection: Small finger to tips gear, nothing larger than a BD #1 C4.

content.description:
This is a top-rope variation and would be a R/X lead. Using the bolted anchor for

Crack Left

/

Right

, use a #1 BD C4 to set up a directional for the prow/face just left of

Crack Left

. The hardest moves are the first 5-10 feet. Then it eases to enjoyable 5.8 face climbing.
content.protection:
If leading, a single #1 BD C4.

Per

skwekel

: this is now fully retrobolted.

content.description: Climb up the right arete of a free standing pillar. Balancy moves and aesthetic position make this a unique route of the area. Easy moves allow the climber to top out the pillar for the full experience.
content.location:
This ascends the free standing pillar in between the

10b

and

5.7

.

content.description:
Start up the wide, R->L angling crack to reach the first bolt. Step right onto the face (crux), and continue up a featured face to the anchor. Use a hand-sized cam in a horizontal rail between the first and second bolts.

Helicopter Premonition and

Origami Dog

share anchors.
content.location:
Begin 40 feet right of

Lord of La Junta

(the giant roof with a horizontal crack).

content.description:
This is the semi-overhanging arête right of

Brain Line

. Begin right of the yellow, overhung rock (the yellow rock is suspect), and climb the arête joining with the top of

Brain Line

after 20 feet. Cams or a juniper tree can be used for an anchor.
content.location:
This is five feet right of

Brain Line

.

content.description: A set of close parallel cracks lines the right edge of the crag. Climb the right crack. At the top, veer left to a bolted anchor.  Large hands help.
content.protection: Nothing smaller than a #2 BD C4.

content.description: Begin by climbing into the "cave" about 10 feet off the ground, then move right out onto the face, and climb steep, featured rock to the top. Some holds may be a little friable.
content.protection: A TR anchor up top takes small to medium-sized cams.
content.location: This climb is found a few yards to the south (climbers left) of the Class 3 downclimb.

content.description: A set of close parallel cracks lines the right edge of the crag. Climb the left crack to a bolted anchor.

Start with a low crux start on a nice overhanging finger/hand crack. Grab the nice sloped jug to pull over the crux, and cruise up to the top from there.

There is a lot of choss on the ledges above the clean crack, so be careful. Anchor off one of the trees up top.
content.protection: A small gear rack from #0.3-2 Camalots.
content.location:
It is the obvious crack between

Keymaker

and

Sport Route Left

.
